item.question: Which of the following commands will print the usage of each mounted filesystem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands would return all lines that contains text between brackets (i.e. [...])?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character, but within brackets means a literal dot. The backslash escapes the next character which means it loses it special meaning, if any, and will be considered literally.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
Select the possible value for mode that caused the file foo to get the above permissions:
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">ls</font> has three positions to show the permissions for owner, group, and others. This means that if it needs to show the setuid permission as well as the execute permission it requires an extra position. Instead of adding an extra position <font face="monospace">ls</font> will show if both setuid and execute permissions are set or not by showing a lowercase or uppercase character <font face="monospace">s</font>. However, <font face="monospace">chmod</font> does not use <font face="monospace">ls</font> its method and requires both <font face="monospace">x</font> and <font face="monospace">s</font> if you want to set both.

item.question: Which command can display the free inodes for all mounted file systems?

item.question: Which file is created or updated when you execute the command <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
At the commandline you set a variable's value with the command export MYVAR=hello.
Afterwards you execute the above script.
When the script finishes you type the command echo $MYVAR.
What would be the output of the last command you executed?
item.hint: The script is started by a child proces. Therefore the variable <font face="monospace">MYVAR</font> in the script is set in the child proces and will be lost when the script finishes.

item.question:
You need to display all files in the current directory that start with at and end with a g.
Choose the best answer.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You have downloaded an archive called atop.tgz.
Which command could you use to verify the checksum of the file?
item.hint: Although the question does not mention the actual checksum used on the file you should be able to answer the question correctly by eliminating all non-existing commands on a standard Linux system.

item.question:
Your current working directory contains the above files.
Which files are shown when you execute the command ls | grep 't[^o].$'?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character and the dollar sign (<font face="monospace">$</font>) means end of the line.

item.question:
If your system is running in runlevel 2 what best describes this runlevel on
a RedHat system?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You issue the above command with root-privileges.
What will happen to your system?
item.choice: Your system will make eating sounds (yum, yum)
Your debian system will be upgraded to the new stable version
Your redhat system will be upgraded to the new release version
Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.correct_answer: Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.hint: Usually you use <font face="monospace">yum upgrade</font> to upgrade the system to a new version but this requires more actions than are mentioned in the question.

item.question:
Suppose that you know that a task deals with the general concept monitoring, but you are not certain what commands are available for monitoring.
Which of the following Linux command lines would be the BEST first step in finding out about available tools?
item.hint: Personally you may find more than one answer correct. The question asks for a first step so you should select a single answer.

You are looking for the string MyString (not mystring) in the file foo.

Select all answers that apply.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: all files created in the directory will belong to the same group as the directory.
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner
it can be used to temporarily lock the directory
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to display the following three columns from /etc/passwd:
"username (first column), user id (third column) and login directory" (sixth column).
Which command will print these columns to screen?
item.hint: Remember what <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> uses as field separator. You may encounter commands as answers which are not covered in the LPI 101 objectives. Usually these are added to confuse you and are usually not correct.

item.question:
You are using disk quota on your system.
With the command ___________ (full path name) you can see disk quota details.
item.hint: The question requires you yo provide the complete path to the command. For instance <font face="monospace">/bin/ls</font>. If you only provide the commandname the answer will be wrong. Beware of typos. If multiple commands provide the asked information provide only one of these commands as answer.

item.question:
You just got a new disk and want to make it accessible for users.
Which command(s) do you require to perform this task?
Select all that apply.
item.hint: The question is about setting up a fresh new harddisk for general usage on a Linux system. You should select all commands you will need to accomplish the task.

item.question:
According to the File Hierarchy Standard some directories are mandatory on the root-filesystem.
Which of the following directories should reside on the root-filesystem.
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The root filesystem must contain the tools and files that are essential to startup the system and be able to repair it.

item.question: Where would you add a library path if the library is currently located in your homedirectory and only temporarily used?
item.choice: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
Add it to <font face="monospace">/etc/modprob.conf</font> and run <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font> afterwards to update the cache-file
Call the system administrator and have her add it to the correct location
item.correct_answer: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will do the same as kill -s INT 3022.
Select all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You installed a new set of shared libraries in /usr/local/mynewlib.
You run the command ldconfig.
However, running the application still causes problems, complaining it cannot find the shared libraries.
What is most likely the cause of this?
item.choice: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
When you install new libraries, you need to recompile or re-install the application.
You forgot to add the library path to the <font face="monospace">PATH</font> variable.
You forgot to reboot the system (the libraries are discovered at kernel initialization).
item.correct_answer: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following Linux commands can be used to create backups of filesystems and directories?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Although the question asks you to select all correct answers it does not mean there are multiple correct answers. However, if there are more than one correct answers you will need to provide them all to get points for this question.

item.question:
You want to move all directories and ONLY directories in you current working directory that start with test to the directory testing.
Which of the following commands would be best to perform this task?
item.hint: The question states you want to MOVE the directories which means you can eliminate one answer immediately. The question also states you want to move ONLY directories which eliminates another answer. Now you are left with two possible answers and it comes down to knowing if the command requires an option or not.

item.question:
Which of the following entries from the file /etc/fstab are correct?
Choose all answers that are correct.
item.hint: Some directories are by default connected to special in-memory filesystems which should not be exported.

item.question: What will be the result of the above command?
item.choice: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
Changes to a directory named <font face="monospace">~guru0</font>
Changes to directory named <font face="monospace">guru0</font> in the current directory

item.question:
You want the system to shutdown at 17:00 this afternoon.
It is now 9:00. Which of the following commands will shutdown the system at 17:00 and sends out a warning message 20 minutes prior to shutting down?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a file?
item.choice: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
the file will be persistent in memory
the file can only be deleted by the owner or a user with root-privileges.
the file can never be deleted by a regular user
item.correct_answer: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
item.hint: Remember we are talking Linux here.

item.question: How would you set the sticky bit on a directory?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You need to install linux on a laptop with a 1.66 GHz processor, 2 GB of RAM and a 160 GB harddisk.
The user made clear he wants support for suspend and hibernation.
How much space on the disk would you allocate to be used as swap?
item.hint: Hibernation will write memory to the swap space. So the minimum amount of swap space required will be the amount of RAM in the system. However, this may be too limited as the system might have used some portion of the swap space to hold inactive memory pages when the physical RAM was or is full. To make sure there will be enough swap space left for hibernation a good rule of thumb is to allocate twice the amount of RAM as swap space.

item.question:
Suppose you know that an application atop is installed on the current system.
You have examined the man and info pages for atop thoroughly.
However, you still have an appetite for more information about atop.
Which of the following directories is the BEST first place to look for further documentation files?
item.hint: The question could be rephrased as: What is the default location for documentation files?

item.question: Considering the command <font face="monospace">dpkg</font> which of the following options are correct?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You enabled quota support for users on the filesystem mounted on /extra.
Which file holds the current quotas for users?
item.hint: The quota system keeps its administration on the filesystem itself. Knowing that the question is about user quota support, you should be able to pick the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following is true about the <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> directory?
item.choice: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
Every directory has a <font face="monospace">lost+found</font> subdirectory.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.correct_answer: It is not mentioned in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
It contains unlinked files found by <font face="monospace">fsck</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.
